content.webTitle: Liverpool’s Nathaniel Clyne thanks Jürgen Klopp’s for rising confidence

fields.headline: Liverpool’s Nathaniel Clyne thanks Klopp for his rising level of confidence
fields.bodyText: Nathaniel Clyne thought his confidence levels were sky high until Jürgen Klopp arrived at Liverpool in early October to increase them even further. This, after all, is a 24-year-old who walked straight off at the end of England’s Euro 2016 qualifier with Slovenia in June because Roy Hodgson did not start him at right-back. Clyne has since proved his worth by becoming first choice for Liverpool, whom he joined for £12.5m in the summer, and England, for whom he started five of the final six qualifiers. And now the appointment of Klopp, who replaced Brendan Rodgers at Anfield, has given Clyne a further boost. “When you come to a new club you may hold back and don’t take so many risks, but now I’ve played a few games I can take more risks,” he says. “I can go out there and express myself and because he has confidence if you lose the ball you don’t worry. You just go out and do it again. “He’s tried to make me more confident in my ability as a player to go and express myself – not to hold back and keep going forward. He said openly: ‘Don’t hold back, you’re a good player, go forward.’ He’s been just working on my confidence really. He’s extra confident in my ability to get forward and to develop as a player.” Of his role under the German, Clyne says: “I’ll say definitely pressing on the front foot, setting the trap for the opposition team, and getting more forward on the pitch, and [being] solid defensively as well.” Despite a near-perfect performance when Liverpool handed Manchester City a lesson in high pressing and relentless energy during their 4-1 victory at the Etihad Stadium on 21 November, Klopp never stopped shouting on the touchline. This is the German’s default mode during games: a waving, berating, demanding taskmaster. As the man nearest the manager for one half of each match Clyne is aware of the act. “You can definitely hear him on the sideline,” the defender says. “If he’s got something to say you can hear him – he always shouts out tactics and [is] always encouraging players to run faster and put more effort into the game.” Like all the very best managers, Klopp has a softer side. “I suppose you don’t want to make a mistake when you’re playing,” Clyne says. “He’s a good manager and obviously he can be a good friend as well.” In Wednesday evening’s Capital One Cup quarter-final at Southampton, Clyne could line up alongside Adam Lallana and Dejan Lovren to make a trio of former Saints making a return to their former club. “The fans are always good to me, so I am hoping for a good reception,” Clyne says, before reality kicks in. “I’m not sure it will be good to see the fans, they booed Adam Lallana and Dejan Lovren [in previous encounters], so hopefully they’ll get the stick. I hope I get a good reception, I guess it will make a good atmosphere.” Liverpool’s 1-0 victory over Swansea City on Sunday was a first home league triumph under Klopp. It left them only six points behind the leaders, City, and Clyne believes they could make a charge for the title. He says: “We have just got to keep on putting in performances like we’ve done in the last few games, keep getting wins, and see where we end up. No one has taken the league by storm, so we have to keep focusing on our game, try and get up there and compete for the league. If you can beat the best at the top it definitely gives us the confidence we can go all the way.” The Capital One Cup also offers the prospect of silverware in Klopp’s first campaign. “I definitely think this is a good chance to win a trophy,” says Clyne. “Get a win over Southampton and we will be in the semi and another step towards the final.” And for him personally? With the Euro 2016 finals in France in the summer, there could be a memorable few months ahead. “It’s a big target, definitely. I want to put in big performances because I know people will be watching and you get picked on form,” says Clyne.
